importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Stacey Abrams narrowly lost the Georgia governor's race to Brian Kemp in 2018, marking a pivotal moment in the effectiveness and sustainability of her voter organizing model.

In the 2020 presidential election, Joe Biden won Georgia, and Democratic senators Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock won seats in a January 2021 runoff, demonstrating the impact of New Georgia Project's voter outreach.
In 2024, Republican turnout surged under Trump, leading to a significant Republican victory despite a larger Democratic vote share, signaling a decline in Democratic momentum despite prior successes.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2013 to 2025 represents the operational lifespan of the New Georgia Project and its affiliated Action Fund, during which they played a major role in shaping Democratic voter engagement in Georgia.

keyTakeAways: The New Georgia Project, founded by Stacey Abrams in 2013, was instrumental in registering and mobilizing nonwhite and young voters in Georgia, particularly in inner-city Atlanta and rural areas.

Despite initial successes in 2018 and 2020, the groups faced financial and legal challenges, including a record $300,000 fine from the Georgia Ethics Commission for illegal election-related fundraising and campaign reporting in 2018.

The closure of the New Georgia Project and its Action Fund raises questions about the long-term sustainability of Abrams’ progressive voter organizing model in a state where Republicans maintain control.
The loss of these groups comes as Democrats seek to reclaim leadership in Georgia, including in the 2026 Senate race for Jon Ossoff and a potential first governor’s race since 1998.
Organizers reported knocking on 4 million doors in 2020, reflecting the scale of outreach, but declining funding and leadership issues have made the operation unsustainable.

The closure is seen as a setback for progressive politics in the Deep South, with experts noting that no comparable outreach model has emerged to replicate the door-knocking and grassroots efforts of the New Georgia Project.

namedEntities.name: Stacey Abrams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democratic politician and founder of the New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stacey Abrams founded the voter turnout groups central to the article, and her political strategy and legacy are directly tied to the success and eventual closure of these organizations.

namedEntities.name: New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Voter registration and turnout organization founded by Stacey Abrams in 2013
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The New Georgia Project was a key Democratic voter organizing force in Georgia, directly responsible for mobilizing nonwhite and young voters across the state.

namedEntities.name: New Georgia Project Action Fund
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Affiliated nonpartisan fund of the New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Action Fund supported the voter outreach efforts of the New Georgia Project and was part of the broader organizational structure that closed down in 2025.

namedEntities.name: Fair Fight
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Another organization founded by Stacey Abrams
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fair Fight, like the New Georgia Project, faced legal losses, raising broader concerns about the sustainability of Abrams’ voter organizing model.

namedEntities.name: Brian Kemp
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kemp represented the Republican incumbent who defeated Abrams in 2018 and later won in a 2022 election, highlighting the political challenge Democrats face in Georgia.

namedEntities.name: Joe Biden
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democrat who won the 2020 U.S. presidential election in Georgia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Biden’s victory in Georgia was a direct result of the voter mobilization efforts of the New Georgia Project, demonstrating its political impact.

namedEntities.name: Jon Ossoff
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democratic U.S. Senator running for re-election in 2026
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ossoff’s campaign is a central focus of Democratic efforts in Georgia, and the closure of voter organizations undermines their long-term capacity to support such races.

namedEntities.name: Raphael Warnock
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democratic U.S. Senator and close ally of Stacey Abrams
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Warnock won Senate seats in 2021 and was listed as CEO of the New Georgia Project, showing organizational ties and political alignment with Abrams.

namedEntities.name: Kamala Harris
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vice President who won 75,000 more Democratic votes than Biden in Georgia in 2024
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Harris’s performance in 2024 illustrates the shift in Republican turnout that undermined Democratic gains despite strong vote totals.

namedEntities.name: Rev. James Woodall
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chair of the board of the New Georgia Project Action Fund
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Woodall led the board in issuing a statement about the closure, signaling leadership responsibility and the decision to discontinue operations.

namedEntities.name: Georgia Ethics Commission
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: State body that issued a record fine against the New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The commission levied a $300,000 fine in January 2025 for illegal campaign finance activities, contributing to financial and organizational decline.

namedEntities.name: Stephanie Jackson Ali
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former policy director of the New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ali provided firsthand insight into the scale and challenges of the organization, including door-knocking efforts and financial struggles.

namedEntities.name: David Emadi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive Director of the Georgia Ethics Commission
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Emadi confirmed compliance with the ethics commission’s order, indicating that legal and financial accountability played a role in the organization’s closure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two voter turnout organizations founded by Stacey Abrams — the New Georgia Project and its affiliated Action Fund — have announced their closure, raising concerns about the sustainability of progressive voter organizing in Georgia. The groups, which registered tens of thousands of voters and were instrumental in helping Democrats win Senate seats in 2021, faced significant legal challenges, including a record $300,000 fine from the Georgia Ethics Commission for illegal fundraising in 2018. Despite their success in mobilizing young and nonwhite voters and contributing to Joe Biden’s 2020 victory, declining funding, leadership issues, and rising Republican turnout — especially in 2024 — have undermined their long-term viability. With Democrats now seeking to win a governor’s race and re-elect Senator Jon Ossoff in 2026, the closure signals a major shift in the political landscape and questions whether Abrams’ model of grassroots, progressive organizing can be sustained in a deeply Republican-leaning state.
title: Georgia Voter Turnout Groups Founded by Stacey Abrams Close Down
